So we looked at very interesting cohorts
of Quebecois who committed suicide,

and had childhood abuse in 100
percent of the cases, and control Quebecois

who died from other reasons,
mostly car accidents
that did not have any report of childhood abuse.

And we first looked at a group
of genes called ribosomal RNA.

These genes encode ribosomal RNA,
which is essentially the basic scaffold
over which proteins are translated.

So the amounts of protein we synthesize in
a cell is determined by the scaffolding.

And the amount scaffolding is determined by
the number of genes of RNA that we express.

So we have 400 copies, and
especially a cell makes a decision,

how many of these 400 copies I use and
how many as -- I keep as frozen assets.

And we know that differences
in protein synthesis are noted

in depressed patients and
also in Alzheimer disease.

And we knew because of a different project
in my lab, by the cancer people in my lab,
that it's regulated by methylation.

So we mapped ribosomal RNA in the
brains, in the hippocampus of people
who committed suicide versus controls.

And this is the same assay I
told you -- bisulfite mapping.

So you see, first of all, the stochastic nature
of methylation that reflects this cartoon

that I showed you, methyl groups going up
and down, and you get a certain balance.

But what was noted, it was a very -- there
was a highly increased level of methylation

in the suicide versus the control, which
was statistically very significant.

And almost in every position on this
gene, the promoter of this gene,

we had statistically significant higher
methylation in the suicide versus control,

which translated into differences
in expression of ribosomal RNA.

So yes, there are differences in methylation
between individuals, and we could associate them

with the health -- a mental health phenotype,
which was in this case, committing suicide.

We don't know whether these differences in
protein synthesis just define that moment

when the person took the
decision to take his life.

Perhaps if he could synthesis
proteins faster, you know,
he would have come up with a different decision or not.

But what we know is that there are
differences in methylation between individuals.
And we can associate them.

So when we sent this paper for publication, you
know, the geneticist say it must be genetic.
There must differences in the sequence.
So we sequence this guy.

We didn't find one single
difference in the sequence.

So all these individuals have identical
sequence, which did not surprise us.

They are all French Quebecois of
a very limited founder's stock,
so they're genetically quite clean.

And here you have an example, people
with the same genetic sequence,
but a completely different epigenetic sequence.

We also showed -- and that's
another property of epigenetics --
that it's region and locus specific.

So in the hippocampus, you'll see this
difference in methylation between the suicide

and the control, but you don't see it
in the cerebellum, another brain region.
And that's what's unique about epigenetics.

It's not inherited, so therefore
it's not in the germline.
If it was germline, it was everywhere.

But it happens in specific tissues
in response to specific signals.

So if the hippocampus got that
signal, the hippocampus will do it,
but the cerebellum will not do it.

And it is also gene-specific because
signals go to specific genes.

And if you measure the total
level of methylation --
this is a nearest neighbor analysis --

you see there's no difference
between suicide and control.

So we have a gene and brain
region specific difference.
And that's what epigenetics is.

That's why it's so hard to map the
epigenome because you really have to map it
in every neuron at one specific point in time.

But we had a problem with this study because
we compared people who committed suicide

and were abused with people who did
not commit suicide and were not abused.

What about people who committed
suicide and were not abused?

So we found them, although there
were -- most of our cases were abuse,
but we found some that were not abuse.
And we compared them.
And now we went to look at the GR.

It's exactly the same promoter that
we found difference in methylation
in the rat in response to maternal care.

So does child abuse leave an imprint
on the GR promoter in the hippocampus,

irrespective of the fact that they
eventually committed suicide or not?
So this is the human promoter that we looked at.
This is the sequence.
And this is the result of the mapping.

So all these sites here show methylation
that is specific to child abuse.

So we can look at this person, who
was 50-years old, and look at the GR,

and those who were abused
have those methylation here.

And those who were not abused don't, even
though both committed suicide eventually.

So there are many avenues leading
to suicide, not just child abuse,
although child abuse is quite common.
But you can see the imprint.

And interestingly, it's the same sequence that
we saw in the rat responsive to maternal care.

So if you compare the overall methylation, you
see no statistical difference between suicide
and control, and a high effect of abuse.

And if you look at the expression,
you see the opposite;

the abused have less GR than
those who are not abused.
So this is a new approach that we took.

This is using the new technologies,
which is whole genome technologies.

So essentially, what we can do now, we can use
an antibody to methylated cytosine

and essentially pull down all the DNA that is
methylated and hybridize it against arrays

that covered whatever we want, the
entire genome, parts of the genome,

every sequence in the genome,
representative sequences of the genome.

And measuring how much methylated the
DNA we pulled at each of these sites,

and now we can compare people who committed
suicide to people who didn't in other groups
and map their methylation at the genomic level.

Here we took an entire chromosome,
chromosome 11,

and where the GR promoter is,
and we mapped their methylation.

And what you see here is the
differential methylation.

So the bioinformatition essentially
took the entire population and looked for areas

with highly statistically significant differences
in methylation between the group

that committed suicide and
the group that didn't.

And you see this peak here of
differential methylation, which maps exactly
to the promoter of the glucocorticoid receptor.

It's another level of proof that indeed
something very important is happening
in the glucocorticoid receptor,

which is probably associated
with early childhood and events.
